channel.title: NYT > Education
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: University of Arkansas Withdraws Job Offer for Emily Suski Over Transgender Stance
item.description: The University of Arkansas withdrew a job offer to a legal scholar after state officials learned that she had signed a legal brief concerning transgender athletes, lawmakers said.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Melyssa St. Michael for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of Arkansas came under political pressure to rescind the choice, state lawmakers said.

item.title: Harvard Slips on a Global Ranking List, as Chinese Schools Surge Ahead
item.description: Harvard still dominates, though it fell to No. 3 on a list measuring academic output. Other American universities are falling farther behind their global peers.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zhejiang University in Hangzhou, China, is now at the top of a global ranking of research output, supplanting Harvard University.

item.title: Judge Proposes Restricting Deportation of Student Activists
item.description: In a case over the First Amendment rights of noncitizen scholars, a federal judge proposed extending protections to members of two academic groups behind a lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Scott Heins for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil speaking in Manhattan last August. Earlier on Thursday, a federal appeals court ruled that he was improperly ordered released by a Federal District Court judge last year. Academic groups have raised alarms over the government’s efforts to deport him.

item.title: Minneapolis Schools Allow Students to Learn Online Amid Fears About ICE
item.description: As immigration agents and protests lead some families to keep children home, schools around the Twin Cities are offering a remote option for the next several weeks.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: Students walked out of Roosevelt High School in Minneapolis in protest on Monday. Several school districts are offering remote learning to students amid the federal immigration crackdown.

item.title: Judge to Weigh Next Steps in Student Activist Deportations Case
item.description: The hearing on Thursday followed up on the court’s sweeping finding in September that noncitizen students had the same free speech rights as citizens.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil and Mohsen Mahdawi, two international students detained by the Trump administration, at a vigil in New York last September.

item.title: U.S. Says It Erred in Deporting Student Traveling for Thanksgiving
item.description: The Trump administration acknowledged it mistakenly deported a college student to Honduras despite a court order barring the removal. But the government has not moved to drop the case.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's lawyer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Any Lucía López Belloza’s high school graduation in Texas. She was detained and later deported in late November while trying to surprise her family with a visit.

item.title: Humanities Endowment Awarding Millions to Western Civilization Programs
item.description: The National Endowment for the Humanities is giving more than $40 million to programs that have been embraced by conservatives as a counterweight to liberal-dominated academia.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of Texas received $10 million to hire faculty members and help “launch academic majors in Strategy and Statecraft and Great Books.”

item.title: Trump Signs Bill Allowing Schools to Serve Whole Milk Again
item.description: The law, which was approved unanimously by Congress late last year, also gives schools more flexibility in serving nondairy milks.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Will Warasila for The New York Times
item.media:description: An elementary school lunch in Montana in 2024.

item.title: What High School Seniors Wrote in Their College Admissions Essays
item.description: Some students are still mentioning their race or immigrant status as the Trump administration cracks down on diversity efforts. But many are avoiding sensitive aspects of their identity.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Mokam
item.media:credit: KT Kanazawich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zhi McMillan, a senior from Virginia, highlighted in his essay an experience at a historical burial ground for African Americans.

item.title: Supreme Court Appears Inclined to Allow States to Bar Transgender Athletes
item.description: The outcome of a pair of cases on Tuesday could affect laws in 27 states that prohibit transgender girls from joining girls’ and women’s sports teams.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Pepper-Jackson, who sued to join her middle school’s girls’ cross-country team when she was 11, asserted that her state’s statute violates Title IX.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Miracle Children,’ by Katie Benner and Erica L. Green
item.description: “Miracle Children” details how a Louisiana school exploited the demand for stories of Black trauma.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Carey
item.category: TM Landry College Preparatory (Breaux Bridge, La)
Miracle Children: Race, Education, and a True Story of False Promises (Book)

item.title: Number of Trans Athletes Affected by Bans Is Low, but the Debate Is Broad
item.description: The people who support barring trans girls from girls’ sports say the debate affects not just transgender athletes but whole teams and sports.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Pepper-Jackson, a transgender athlete in West Virginia, holds a discus.

item.title: University of Michigan Picks Kent D. Syverud, Syracuse Leader, as Its Next President
item.description: Kent D. Syverud will become the fifth person to run Michigan since the start of 2022, inheriting a school that also has debated diversity.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of Michigan campus in Ann Arbor.

item.title: 2 Students Behind Challenges to Trans Athlete Laws
item.description: One sued to join her middle school girls’ cross-country team in West Virginia and the other to join the women’s track and cross-country teams at her university in Idaho.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Pepper-Jackson sued her state in 2021 to join her middle school girls’ cross-country team.

item.title: One Year of Trump. The Time to Act Is Now, While We Still Can.
item.description: The United States is broken, but not in every way.
item.dc:creator: M. Gessen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Virginia’s New Governor Moves Swiftly to Overhaul State University Boards
item.description: Abigail Spanberger, a Democrat, appointed new board members at three state schools, hours after she was sworn in as Virginia’s first female governor.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: Gov. Abigail Spanberger of Virginia took a variety of executive actions during her first few hours in office on Saturday.

item.title: A.I. Is Coming to Class. These Professors Want to Ease Your Worries.
item.description: Even as some instructors remain fervently opposed to chatbots, other writing and English professors are trying to improve them.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman and Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Attitudes toward artificial intelligence are evolving, with some academic groups saying students must learn how to use it critically.

item.title: Judge Recommends U.S. Issue Visa to Student Who Was Deported in Error
item.description: A federal prosecutor apologized this week, saying an ICE officer made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's attorney, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Any Lucia López Belloza celebrating her high school graduation in Texas last year. She was attending college in Massachusetts before her deportation in November.

item.title: Trump Administration Delays Forced Collections on Student Loan Defaults
item.description: The Education Department has temporarily paused a plan to seize tax refunds and begin garnishing the wages of borrowers who have defaulted on their student loans.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Education Department said it was postponing its plan to gradually resume garnishing the wages of those who have defaulted on their student loans.

item.title: Some U.Va. Board Members Asked to Resign as Gov. Abigail Spanberger Takes Power
item.description: After months of upheaval at the state’s flagship university, a new Democratic governor appeared ready to shake up the school’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: Virginia’s governor-elect, Abigail Spanberger, will be sworn in on Saturday.
